docs.lead_paragraph: A private school that has operated from a rather elegant former bank building in Newark's developing Arts District for the last 10 years has put the structure on the market.

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (AMC) BROKEN TRAIL -- A veteran cowboy and his estranged nephew save five Chinese girls from prostitution while running 500 horses from Oregon to Wyoming in 1897 in this two-part made-for-television movie. Sitting tall in the lead saddles: Robert Duvall, who lives in rural Virginia, and Thomas Haden Church (above left, with Mr. Duvall), who calls a Texas ranch home. 6 P.M. (MSNBC) DARFUR: CAUGHT IN THE CROSSFIRE -- Ann Curry, digital camera in hand, reports on the ethnic cleansing that has terrorized the Darfur region of Sudan and provides the images to back it up. 7 P.M. (CNBC) DLIFE: YOUR DIABETES LIFE -- This series on coping with diabetes begins a new season with a look at health care and insurance, and offers fast-food alternatives for when home cooking isn't an option. 8 P.M. (TNT) HALF LIGHT -- This comeback vehicle for Demi Moore, who plays a mystery writer trying to put her life back together after the death of her 5-year-old son, went straight to DVD. But fans say its setting -- an isolated fishing village in Scotland -- and its haunting story line are big screen worthy. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE -- Emeril Lagasse indulges in a little goodnatured competition with his friend and network rival Mario Batali. Their battleground: Italy, or at least its food, with which they demonstrate their own versions of dishes like linguine with red clam sauce, ragu Bolognese and duck scalloppine. 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) LET'S JUST PLAY: GO HEALTHY CHALLENGE -- This special checks in, for the second time, on four children committed to improving the diet and exercise habits not only of themselves but of their families, friends and communities. 9 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- For 12 seasons, James Lipton has leveled his sometimes odd questions at the best of the best, even though a few of them can only loosely be categorized as actors. (Elton John?) In this 200th episode, Mr. Lipton lobs a few at Dustin Hoffman (right), who seems to take them in stride. 10 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES -- Darius's fun and games come to an end when Katie, in revenge for being raped in Spain, kidnaps him. And Conrad and Tanya get engaged. For now. 10 P.M. (Showtime) HUFF -- The season is over, but the angst goes on -- at least in this episode, in which Huff answers Russell's call, Izzy visits Teddy, Byrd vents and Beth (Paget Brewster, left) tells Alec where they stand. And he's not going to like it. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

docs.lead_paragraph: BANKING DATA EXAMINED -- Under a secret Bush administration program begun weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, counterterrorism officials have gained access to financial records from a vast international database and examined banking transactions involving thousands of Americans and others in the United States, according to government and industry officials. [Page A1.] FUND INVESTIGATION -- One of the nation's most prominent hedge funds, Pequot Capital Management, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for possible insider trading, according to officials. The S.E.C. declined to confirm or deny that it was investigating Pequot. [A1.] BIAS SUIT RULING FAVORS WORKERS -- In a 9-to-0 ruling, the Supreme Court substantially enhanced legal protection against retaliation for employees who complain about discrimination or harassment on the job. [A22.] JUSTICES DROP PATENT CASE -- The Supreme Court backed away from ruling on a closely watched case that could have set boundaries on what discoveries and inventions can be patented. The court dismissed the case, which effectively upheld the medical diagnostic testing patent at issue. [C3.] ZOCOR PATENT -- Today, Merck's cholesterol-lowering drug Zocor loses its United States patent protection. The change will cost Merck billions of dollars a year, but it could be nearly as damaging to Pfizer, whose rival drug, Lipitor, is the world's most popular medicine. [C1.] LORD & TAYLOR DEAL -- A team of real estate and private equity investors said they would buy the 48-store Lord & Taylor department store chain from Federated Department Stores for $1.2 billion in cash. [C1.] NOVELL OUSTS OFFICERS -- The software company Novell ousted its chief executive, Jack L. Messman, and chief financial officer, Joseph S. Tibbetts Jr., in the latest effort to reverse lackluster performance and a sagging share price. Mr. Messman and Mr. Tibbetts led the company as it shifted its focus from networking software to the Linux operating system and related services. [C2.] INTEREST WORRIES DEPRESS STOCKS -- Stocks fell as investors bet that the Federal Reserve would keep raising interest rates even as economic growth shows signs of slowing. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 60.35 points to end at 11,019.11. [C9.] LEADING INDICATORS SLIP -- The Index of Leading Economic Indicators slipped 0.6 percent in May to 137.9, the Conference Board said, suggesting that the nation's economy is likely to cool in the coming months. [C9.] COAL'S COST -- A coal mining boom is devastating large swaths of north China, where some of the nation's richest coal deposits lie. [C1.] THE CLAUSE -- Tucked into the Coast Guard budget bill is language that would allow Nabors Industries, a big oil drilling company, access to offshore supply business open only to American companies. Nabors moved its tax headquarters to Bermuda and its legal headquarters to Barbados to avoid American taxes. [C1.] ESTATE TAX VOTE -- The House voted 269 to 156 to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth permanently for all but a sliver of the nation's wealthiest families. The action sets the stage for a decisive vote in the Senate next week. [C3.] OPTIMISM ABOUT A TRADE DEAL -- A month after he warned that the five-year negotiations for a global trade agreement were in the ''red zone,'' the head of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, left, said he had grown considerably more optimistic about the odds of a deal. [C4.] CHRYSLER MAY REVIVE DISCOUNTS -- The Chrysler Group said it was considering bringing back its employee discount program of last summer to clear out a backlog of cars and trucks on showroom lots. The program offers consumers the same deals that employees receive. [C3.] FED BANK PRESIDENT TO RETIRE -- Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said that he would retire on Oct. 1. His decision creates a third vacancy on the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets interest rates. [C3.] AIRLINE PRICE-FIXING INQUIRY -- British and United States agencies are investigating a possible conspiracy to illegally fix the amounts of fuel surcharges imposed on passengers on long-distance flights to and from Britain. [C3.] UKRAINE MAY REVIEW GAS DEAL -- Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who is poised to return as Ukraine's prime minister, vowed to review a disputed deal with Russia on natural gas imports, setting the stage for a new confrontation that could disrupt her country's economy and threaten supplies of Russian gas to Europe. [A5.] SCRAMBLE FOR ASSETS -- The bidding war surrounding PCCW, Hong Kong's largest telecommunications company, is taking on a new twist. Everyone seems to want the major telecom assets of PCCW, though not the company itself. [C5.] LAYOFFS AT INSURER -- Allianz, the insurance giant, announced it would lay off 7,480 employees, about 4 percent of its worldwide work force, as part of an overhaul aimed at raising profitability. Almost all of the layoffs will be in Germany. [C5.] ONLINE THE HOME AUCTION -- As sellers seek more control in today's real estate market, they may decide to put their houses under the gavel. A report is at www.nytimes.com/realestate. MAKING A RUN FOR IT -- Over all, people who jog are less likely to have a heart attack over time than if they had not been joggers. A report by Jane Brody can be found at nytimes.com/health. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A daily report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.
